This email is with reference to your concern regarding the order # 652957864421752832-39206. Please accept my sincere apologies for the inconvenience caused to you.
 
As per the update, strong feedback is shared with the respective departments and also we are working to solve the issue on priority basis. PharmEasy will ensure all appropriate actions are taken to prevent similar situations from happening in the future.

Please consider this as a one-off instance as we aim to provide the best of services to our customers and such instances are very rare.

notes.body: Hello Kumar,  Greetings from PharmEasy!  With regards to your order #651237683581005824-46576, I am sorry to know you have not received the medicine you ordered, DR. I apologise for the inconvenience caused to you.  I am highlighting your concern to the Escalation team, and our team will investigate it. If the medicine is found to be missing, the refund amount of Rs. 1836.45 will be initiated. Post initiation of refund, the amount of Rs. 782.15 will be credited to your payment source within 5 to 7 working days, and the amount of Rs. 1054.3 will be credited to your PharmEasy wallet in 24 hours.  You can expect the resolution within 24 to 48 hours. helpdesk_ticket.description:
https://aventis-learning.com/course/effective-stakeholder-engagement/


** Winning Stakeholders: Strategies to Engage, Influence & Inspire
------------------------------------------------------------

Do you know how well your stakeholders are engaged?

In today’s dynamic business environment, strong stakeholder engagement is essential for strategic success and sustainable growth. It helps organisations understand stakeholder needs, build trust, and adapt strategies—resulting in improved communication, enhanced brand reputation, and a competitive advantage.

By effectively engaging stakeholders, you can anticipate their concerns, foster meaningful relationships, and align your initiatives for long-term impact. This not only supports smoother execution of business activities, from technology rollouts to cultural change, but also strengthens your organisation’s overall effectiveness and credibility.


** Learning Outcomes
------------------------------------------------------------

What you will be learning on this 1-day Stakeholder Engagement
* Understand Stakeholder Engagement: Define stakeholder engagement and apply the Five-Step Approach for effective management.
* Map and Categorize Stakeholders: Identify key stakeholders and group them using stakeholder mapping techniques.
* Gain Advocates and Buy-Ins: Review stakeholder mapping, identify advocates, and secure buy-ins for successful collaboration.
* Engage Difficult Stakeholders: Learn the steps to effectively engage challenging stakeholders and manage conflicts.
* Master Negotiation and Action Planning: Apply negotiation tactics to adapt to different situations, create a dual action plan, and ensure thorough follow-ups.


** Course Details
------------------------------------------------------------
------------------------------------------------------------
Jan

13

Tue



** Classroom
------------------------------------------------------------


** HRP Code: AV0284

Course Title: Effective Stakeholder Engagement: How to Engage, Inspire and Manage Difficult Stakeholders

Time:  9.00am to 5.00pm

Venue: Classroom @Holiday Inn Orchard City Centre or Concorde Hotel or Holiday Inn Atrium (Halal)

Fees: SGD 680.00 (excluding GST)
------------------------------------------------------------
✨ Bonus
* Register 3 or more participants together to enjoy an exclusive group discount
* ? Paid NTUC members can enjoy up to 50% UTAP funding

Register For Classroom Session (https://aventis-learning.com/course/effective-stakeholder-engagement/?getregistration=a006F00003UYV6vQAH&cohort=a01OQ00000ENfSIYA1&c=28763)


** Course Outline
------------------------------------------------------------

Module 1: Workshop Introduction
* Empowering Stakeholder Engagement: Workshop Objectives and Agenda
* Strategic Significance of Stakeholder Engagement for Organizational Excellence

Module 2: Navigating Stakeholder Landscapes: Methods for Identification and Analysis
* Uncovering Stakeholders: Methods and Techniques for Identification
* Maximizing Stakeholder Influence: Methods for Effective Mapping and Analysis
* Unlocking Stakeholder Expectations: Approaches to Gain Insight into Interests, Needs, and Expectations

Module 3:  Stakeholder Engagement Strategies
* Dynamic Stakeholder Engagement: Strategies for Engaging Stakeholders with Varied Levels of Influence and Interest
* Strengthening Stakeholder Relationships: Approaches to Establish Trust and Enhance Credibility
* Multi-channel Engagement: Approaches for Maximizing Communication and Engagement with Stakeholders

Module 4: Stakeholder Engagement Tools and Techniques
* Collaborative Approaches: Methods for Promoting Stakeholder Communication and Cooperation
* Stakeholder engagement frameworks (IAP2, AA1000SES, RISE)
* Digital Engagement Strategies: Harnessing Technology for Effective Stakeholder Interaction

Module 5: Collaborative Decision-Making
* Stakeholder Inclusion: The Key Significance of Involving Stakeholders in Decision-Making
* Multi-Stakeholder Dialogue: Methods for Encouraging Collaboration in Decision-Making
* Integrated Value Creation: Strategies for Aligning Stakeholder Interests with Organizational Objective

Module 6: Building Strong Stakeholder Relationships
* Continuous Engagement and Communication: Approaches for Sustaining Long-Term Relationships with Stakeholders
* Trust-Based Engagement Strategies: Techniques for Building Trust and Fostering Effective Stakeholder Relationships
* Social Media Monitoring and Sentiment Analysis: Leveraging Digital Tools to Gauge Stakeholder Sentiments and Gather Real-time Feedback

Module 7: Putting it into Practice: Group Activity
* Stakeholder Engagement Innovation Lab: Collaborative Group Work for Resolving Engagement Challenges
* Best Practices Exchange: Sharing Solutions and Facilitating Peer-to Peer Discussions on Stakeholder Engagement

Module 8: Workshop Wrap-up and Next Steps
* Recap of key concepts and learnings
* Actionable Takeaways: Translating Workshop Insights into Actionable Steps for Individual Work


** Who Should Attend
------------------------------------------------------------

This course is aimed at anyone seeking to lead, shape and achieve positive outcomes.
* Project management professionals, including Project Managers, Program Managers, Project Directors, Portfolio Managers and Project Management Office (PMO) Managers;
* Consultants, researchers and analysts including Change Managers, business analysts. Management Consultants, Business Consultants, Business Analysts, Requirements Managers, Independent Consultants and Business Owners
* Those responsible for managing resources, including Practice Managers, Line Managers and Resource Managers
* Business Managers and leaders, including Executive Management, Line Managers / Operations Managers with project responsibilities
* Those responsible for project funding and benefits management, including Project Sponsors, Finance Directors, Project Directors, Account Managers, Account Directors
* New and aspiring managers looking to develop and progress their careers and needing to learn how to cultivate and develop business relationships


** Trainer Profile
------------------------------------------------------------

Personal and Organisational Effectiveness Master Trainer and Certified Advanced Behavioural Analyst: Ivan Phua

Ivan Phua is an accomplished professional distinguished by his engaging presence, in-depth knowledge, and unwavering commitment to driving organizational excellence. With a recognized track record and esteemed reputation, he consistently delivers exceptional results across diverse professional environments, earning significant respect in his field.

﻿Ivan's captivating communication style fosters trust and collaboration, enabling him to build strong relationships with diverse audiences. Driven by a relentless pursuit of excellence, he sets ambitious goals and inspires individuals to reach their full potential. His approach combines deep expertise with a proactive problem-solving mindset, empowering team members to embrace challenges and achieve extraordinary outcomes. Through his strategic leadership and motivational approach, Ivan transforms potential into tangible success, making a meaningful impact in every professional engagement.

============================================================

General Enquiries / Looking for Group Discounts?
Ms Calista │ Call/WhatsApp: 8040 9568 │ Call: 6720 3333 │ Email: training.aventis@gmail.com

helpdesk_ticket.subject: ? Navigate Difficult Stakeholders with Confidence
helpdesk_ticket.description_html:
Up to 50% Utap Funding! Get tools to communicate better, manage expectations, and work smoothly with the people who matter most.

Winning Stakeholders: Strategies to Engage, Influence & Inspire
Do you know how well your stakeholders are engaged?

In today’s dynamic business environment, strong stakeholder engagement is essential for strategic success and sustainable growth. It helps organisations understand stakeholder needs, build trust, and adapt strategies—resulting in improved communication, enhanced brand reputation, and a competitive advantage.

By effectively engaging stakeholders, you can anticipate their concerns, foster meaningful relationships, and align your initiatives for long-term impact. This not only supports smoother execution of business activities, from technology rollouts to cultural change, but also strengthens your organisation’s overall effectiveness and credibility.

Learning Outcomes
What you will be learning on this 1-day Stakeholder Engagement
  • Understand Stakeholder Engagement: Define stakeholder engagement and apply the Five-Step Approach for effective management.
  • Map and Categorize Stakeholders: Identify key stakeholders and group them using stakeholder mapping techniques.
  • Gain Advocates and Buy-Ins: Review stakeholder mapping, identify advocates, and secure buy-ins for successful collaboration.
  • Engage Difficult Stakeholders: Learn the steps to effectively engage challenging stakeholders and manage conflicts.
  • Master Negotiation and Action Planning: Apply negotiation tactics to adapt to different situations, create a dual action plan, and ensure thorough follow-ups.

Course Details
Jan

13

Tue

 

Classroom 

 

HRP Code: AV0284

Course Title: Effective Stakeholder Engagement: How to Engage, Inspire and Manage Difficult Stakeholders

Time:  9.00am to 5.00pm

Venue: Classroom @Holiday Inn Orchard City Centre or Concorde Hotel or Holiday Inn Atrium (Halal)

Fees: SGD 680.00 (excluding GST)


 ✨ Bonus
  • Register 3 or more participants together to enjoy an exclusive group discount
  • 💳 Paid NTUC members can enjoy up to 50% UTAP funding
Register For Classroom Session

Course Outline
Module 1: Workshop Introduction
  • Empowering Stakeholder Engagement: Workshop Objectives and Agenda 
  • Strategic Significance of Stakeholder Engagement for Organizational Excellence
Module 2: Navigating Stakeholder Landscapes: Methods for Identification and Analysis 
  • Uncovering Stakeholders: Methods and Techniques for Identification
  • Maximizing Stakeholder Influence: Methods for Effective Mapping and Analysis 
  • Unlocking Stakeholder Expectations: Approaches to Gain Insight into Interests, Needs, and Expectations
Module 3:  Stakeholder Engagement Strategies 
  • Dynamic Stakeholder Engagement: Strategies for Engaging Stakeholders with Varied Levels of Influence and Interest 
  • Strengthening Stakeholder Relationships: Approaches to Establish Trust and Enhance Credibility 
  • Multi-channel Engagement: Approaches for Maximizing Communication and Engagement with Stakeholders
Module 4: Stakeholder Engagement Tools and Techniques
  • Collaborative Approaches: Methods for Promoting Stakeholder Communication and Cooperation 
  • Stakeholder engagement frameworks (IAP2, AA1000SES, RISE) 
  • Digital Engagement Strategies: Harnessing Technology for Effective Stakeholder Interaction 
Module 5: Collaborative Decision-Making
  • Stakeholder Inclusion: The Key Significance of Involving Stakeholders in Decision-Making 
  • Multi-Stakeholder Dialogue: Methods for Encouraging Collaboration in Decision-Making 
  • Integrated Value Creation: Strategies for Aligning Stakeholder Interests with Organizational Objective
Module 6: Building Strong Stakeholder Relationships
  • Continuous Engagement and Communication: Approaches for Sustaining Long-Term Relationships with Stakeholders 
  • Trust-Based Engagement Strategies: Techniques for Building Trust and Fostering Effective Stakeholder Relationships
  • Social Media Monitoring and Sentiment Analysis: Leveraging Digital Tools to Gauge Stakeholder Sentiments and Gather Real-time Feedback
Module 7: Putting it into Practice: Group Activity
  • Stakeholder Engagement Innovation Lab: Collaborative Group Work for Resolving Engagement Challenges 
  • Best Practices Exchange: Sharing Solutions and Facilitating Peer-to Peer Discussions on Stakeholder Engagement
Module 8: Workshop Wrap-up and Next Steps 
  • Recap of key concepts and learnings 
  • Actionable Takeaways: Translating Workshop Insights into Actionable Steps for Individual Work

Who Should Attend
This course is aimed at anyone seeking to lead, shape and achieve positive outcomes.
  • Project management professionals, including Project Managers, Program Managers, Project Directors, Portfolio Managers and Project Management Office (PMO) Managers;
  • Consultants, researchers and analysts including Change Managers, business analysts. Management Consultants, Business Consultants, Business Analysts, Requirements Managers, Independent Consultants and Business Owners
  • Those responsible for managing resources, including Practice Managers, Line Managers and Resource Managers
  • Business Managers and leaders, including Executive Management, Line Managers / Operations Managers with project responsibilities
  • Those responsible for project funding and benefits management, including Project Sponsors, Finance Directors, Project Directors, Account Managers, Account Directors
  • New and aspiring managers looking to develop and progress their careers and needing to learn how to cultivate and develop business relationships

Trainer Profile
Personal and Organisational Effectiveness Master Trainer and Certified Advanced Behavioural Analyst: Ivan Phua
Ivan Phua is an accomplished professional distinguished by his engaging presence, in-depth knowledge, and unwavering commitment to driving organizational excellence. With a recognized track record and esteemed reputation, he consistently delivers exceptional results across diverse professional environments, earning significant respect in his field.
﻿Ivan's captivating communication style fosters trust and collaboration, enabling him to build strong relationships with diverse audiences. Driven by a relentless pursuit of excellence, he sets ambitious goals and inspires individuals to reach their full potential. His approach combines deep expertise with a proactive problem-solving mindset, empowering team members to embrace challenges and achieve extraordinary outcomes. Through his strategic leadership and motivational approach, Ivan transforms potential into tangible success, making a meaningful impact in every professional engagement.

helpdesk_ticket.description:
Hi Sunita, We had replied on 1st. Please find attached. Please give
reference of the same to the customer.

On Wed, Dec 3, 2025 at 12:55 PM sunita saini <sunita.saini@aarman.in> wrote:

> Hi Piyasa,
>
> As discussed, please prioritize the case.
>
> Regards,
>
> Sunita Saini
>
> On Tue, Dec 2, 2025 at 10:56 AM sunita saini <sunita.saini@aarman.in>
> wrote:
>
>> Hi Namo,
>>
>> As per our conversation yesterday, you were going to discuss this
>> customer concern with your internal team. Please share an update on the
>> discussion so that we can connect with the customer accordingly.
>>
>> Regards,
>>
>> Sunita Saini
>>
>> On Fri, Nov 28, 2025 at 6:05 PM sunita saini <sunita.saini@aarman.in>
>> wrote:
>>
>>> Hi Team,
>>>
>>> We connected with the customer regarding the reported issue, and she
>>> shared the following concerns:
>>>
>>>    -
>>>
>>>    She is seeking clarity on compensation and mentioned that she will
>>>    be discussing the matter further with the Pharmeasy legal team.
>>>    -
>>>
>>>    As per her understanding, if the product was found damaged,
>>>    PharmEasy should have reported the matter to the FDA (VOC).
>>>    -
>>>
>>>    She also stated that if any external factors were responsible for
>>>    the issue, appropriate action should have been taken against the retailer
>>>    partner.
>>>    -
>>>
>>>    The customer is requesting confirmation on who is at fault in this
>>>    case and what action is taken.
>>>    -
>>>
>>>    Additionally, she has asked for all *communication documents
>>>    exchanged with Alembic*, (*raj.bagarwal@alembic.co.in).*
>>>
>>> *Regards,*
>>>

  • She also stated that if any external factors were responsible for the issue, appropriate action should have been taken against the retailer partner.

  • Additionally, she has asked for all communication documents exchanged with Alembic, (raj.bagarwal@alembic.co.in).

This email is with reference to the concern raised for order Id 367500714414575616-35233.
We tried contacting you. However, the call went unanswered.
As per the update received after a thorough investigation,
1. Batch of said product was manufactured and packed as per the standards.

Based on the investigation, we can assure that neither it is a product related issue nor packaging related, this could have been an isolated case of improper handling and/or storage of a particular pack which might have damaged the particular pack.

They are a 115-year-old law-abiding company that follows stringent quality control measures at every step of the manufacturing and packaging process to produce and deliver quality medicines.

Also, share the confirmation whether you wish to return the medicine, so that we can raise a return request for the said medicine.




Warm Regards,
Afrin Sayyed.

---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: namrata adeshra <namrata_adeshra@yahoo.com>
Date: Tue, Sep 2, 2025 at 11:43 PM
Subject: Response to Your Legal Reply – Defective Medicine Complaint
To: PharmEasy <care@pharmeasy.in>, dhaval@pharmeasy.in <dhaval@pharmeasy.in>, legal@axelia.in <legal@axelia.in>


To,
The Legal & Management Team
Pharmeasy
Dear Sir/Madam,
I acknowledge receipt of your legal response regarding my complaint about the defective strip of Richar CR 100 mg tablets purchased through your platform. After reviewing your reply, I must place the following points on record:
1. Your Role as Seller/Distributor
Pharmeasy acted as the point of sale. You collected payment, facilitated delivery, and positioned yourself as the consumer-facing entity. Under the Consumer Protection Act, 2019, and the Drugs & Cosmetics Act, 1940, you are part of the supply chain and cannot disclaim liability entirely by stating you are “just a third-party platform.” Consumer rights are statutory and cannot be waived by contract.
2. Refund ≠ Resolution
When I first raised the issue in November 2023, Pharmeasy collected the defective strip and issued a refund. This action itself amounts to an acknowledgment that the product was defective and unfit for consumption. However, issuing a refund is not a substitute for investigating the root cause, especially in pharmaceuticals where public health is at stake.
3. Failure to Escalate
Despite evidence of a visibly unsafe drug, Pharmeasy did not escalate the matter to Alembic (the manufacturer) or the FDA authorities. As a licensed distributor, this was your duty. Your inaction meant the potential risk to thousands of patients consuming the same batch was ignored.
3A. Failure to Inspect and Report
By collecting the returned medicine, Pharmeasy assumed custody of defective stock. You had a clear responsibility to inspect it and report the defect to the manufacturer and regulatory authorities. Instead, you treated the issue as a simple financial dispute and closed it with a refund, ignoring your statutory duty of care under the Drugs & Cosmetics Act, 1940.
4. Medicines Are Not Ordinary Goods
Pharmaceuticals are life-critical products. A refund cannot be considered the end of the matter when a product that is supposed to save lives is visibly defective, with a black substance oozing out. Such a defect makes the medicine unfit for human consumption regardless of alleged storage conditions.
5. Recurrence Confirms Negligence
The fact that I experienced the same issue again — and still retain the second defective strip — shows this is not an isolated case. Had Pharmeasy acted responsibly during the first incident, conducted proper inspection, and escalated to Alembic or FDA, this recurrence may have been prevented.
6. Pattern of Denial
Your legal reply attempts to disclaim liability entirely. However, both manufacturer and seller are jointly and severally liable under the Consumer Protection Act, 2019. By refusing to accept any accountability, Pharmeasy creates a dangerous gap in the supply chain where no one takes responsibility for defective medicines.

Final Position

  • Pharmeasy’s handling of this matter reflects negligence and a failure in basic consumer protection obligations.
  • I was accommodating enough to return the first strip in good faith. However, when the issue recurred, my concerns escalated. Calling my stance unreasonable is not correct.
  • I am still in possession of the defective strip, which is clear proof of abnormality and unfitness for consumption. 
I remain open to a fair and amicable resolution. However, if Pharmeasy continues to disclaim liability, I will be compelled to pursue remedies before the Consumer Forum, FDA authorities, and CDSCO, seeking damages from both Alembic and Pharmeasy.
Please reconsider your position and come forward with a constructive settlement proposal within 3 days of this email.
Sincerely,
Namrata

notes.body:
Hi Piyasa,

Customer has replied today on your 1st Dec email
Namrata <https://pharmeasy.freshdesk.com/a/contacts/43049294703>
replied
an hour ago (Wed, 3 Dec 2025 at 4:26 PM)

To:"Legal Axelia" <legal@axelia.in>
Cc:care@pharmeasy.in
Dear Team,
This email is my final request for clarity and documentary proof regarding
the defective *Richar CR 100 mg* strip supplied via your platform. I set
out my demands below — please respond fully within 5 working days. If you
do not, I will proceed to file complaints in the Consumer Court and with
regulatory authorities.
1. Re-send the promised mail and report
Your agent told me on our call that he would forward the November 1, 2023
email and the investigation summary again. I have not received it. Please
forward that exact email and any attachments (or provide server
logs/screenshots proving it was sent) immediately.
2. Produce documentary proof of escalation and reply from Alembic
You have repeatedly asserted that you escalated the complaint to Alembic
and received their investigation findings. Alembic, however, contends they
did not receive such escalation. Provide the following without delay:

   - Copy of the email/request sent by your client to Alembic (with
   timestamps).
   - Copy of the response/reply from Alembic (with timestamps).
   - Any internal notes, ticket IDs, or attachments exchanged regarding the
   investigation.

3. Explain who is legally/operationally at fault
If Alembic’s report clears the manufacturer, who is at fault then? As a
consumer I require clarity:

   - If the manufacturer is not at fault, has your client identified the
   retailer/seller from whom the product was procured?
   - Has any action been taken against that retailer
   (suspension/termination/investigation)?
   - Was any complaint or show-cause initiated against that retailer?
   Please provide proof.

4. Manufacturing timeline, storage & safety concern
The product was manufactured only 2–3 months prior to the defect becoming
visible. If a medicine degrades or shows contamination within such a short
period (given the declared shelf life exceeds two years), this is a serious
safety concern. Your communications do not address:

   - How a properly manufactured drug could degrade so rapidly;
   - Whether retailers/distributors in the supply chain were audited for
   storage conditions; and
   - Whether other units from the same batch were identified and
   quarantined or recalled.
   Provide details and documentary proof.

5. Confidentiality is not a shield in matters of public safety
You continue to refuse to share the manufacturer’s report citing
confidentiality. Explain the legal basis for withholding information from
the affected consumer: cite the exact statute, rule, or clause that permits
you to withhold drug quality investigation summaries from a complainant. If
no lawful basis exists, you must disclose the summary of findings to me
immediately. Withholding such material in the name of confidentiality,
where public safety is implicated, is unacceptable.
6. Retailer/seller accountability & corrective steps
If your client’s investigation finds the manufacturer is not responsible,
you must confirm:

   - the identity of the retailer/seller from whom the product was sourced;
   - whether that retailer has been suspended/blocked pending inquiry; and
   - what corrective actions (if any) have been taken to prevent
   distribution of other affected units. Provide documentary proof.

7. Failure to respond is actionable
If you cannot produce the requested documents or lawful justification for
withholding them within 5 working days, I will interpret your silence or
non-compliance as:
a) evidence that no credible investigation was carried out; or
b) deliberate withholding of material information regarding a public-safety
defect.
Either conclusion will lead me to file complaints for: deficiency in
service, unfair trade practice, negligent handling of drug safety
complaints, and pursue remedies before the Consumer Forum and regulatory
authorities (FDA/CDSCO). I will also seek disclosure orders for the
withheld documents in court.
This is my final communication prior to legal escalation. I expect a full
and substantiated reply within 5 working days.
Regards,
Namrata

Hi Team,

Kindly refer to the email below and confirm whether we have responded to the customer or had any communication with the customer.

Regards,
Axelia Legal Team

---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: namrata adeshra <namrata_adeshra@yahoo.com>
Date: Tue, Sep 2, 2025 at 11:43 PM
Subject: Response to Your Legal Reply – Defective Medicine Complaint
To: PharmEasy <care@pharmeasy.in>, dhaval@pharmeasy.in <dhaval@pharmeasy.in>, legal@axelia.in <legal@axelia.in>


To,
The Legal & Management Team
Pharmeasy
Dear Sir/Madam,
I acknowledge receipt of your legal response regarding my complaint about the defective strip of Richar CR 100 mg tablets purchased through your platform. After reviewing your reply, I must place the following points on record:
1. Your Role as Seller/Distributor
Pharmeasy acted as the point of sale. You collected payment, facilitated delivery, and positioned yourself as the consumer-facing entity. Under the Consumer Protection Act, 2019, and the Drugs & Cosmetics Act, 1940, you are part of the supply chain and cannot disclaim liability entirely by stating you are “just a third-party platform.” Consumer rights are statutory and cannot be waived by contract.
2. Refund ≠ Resolution
When I first raised the issue in November 2023, Pharmeasy collected the defective strip and issued a refund. This action itself amounts to an acknowledgment that the product was defective and unfit for consumption. However, issuing a refund is not a substitute for investigating the root cause, especially in pharmaceuticals where public health is at stake.
3. Failure to Escalate
Despite evidence of a visibly unsafe drug, Pharmeasy did not escalate the matter to Alembic (the manufacturer) or the FDA authorities. As a licensed distributor, this was your duty. Your inaction meant the potential risk to thousands of patients consuming the same batch was ignored.
3A. Failure to Inspect and Report
By collecting the returned medicine, Pharmeasy assumed custody of defective stock. You had a clear responsibility to inspect it and report the defect to the manufacturer and regulatory authorities. Instead, you treated the issue as a simple financial dispute and closed it with a refund, ignoring your statutory duty of care under the Drugs & Cosmetics Act, 1940.
4. Medicines Are Not Ordinary Goods
Pharmaceuticals are life-critical products. A refund cannot be considered the end of the matter when a product that is supposed to save lives is visibly defective, with a black substance oozing out. Such a defect makes the medicine unfit for human consumption regardless of alleged storage conditions.
5. Recurrence Confirms Negligence
The fact that I experienced the same issue again — and still retain the second defective strip — shows this is not an isolated case. Had Pharmeasy acted responsibly during the first incident, conducted proper inspection, and escalated to Alembic or FDA, this recurrence may have been prevented.
6. Pattern of Denial
Your legal reply attempts to disclaim liability entirely. However, both manufacturer and seller are jointly and severally liable under the Consumer Protection Act, 2019. By refusing to accept any accountability, Pharmeasy creates a dangerous gap in the supply chain where no one takes responsibility for defective medicines.

Final Position

  • Pharmeasy’s handling of this matter reflects negligence and a failure in basic consumer protection obligations.
  • I was accommodating enough to return the first strip in good faith. However, when the issue recurred, my concerns escalated. Calling my stance unreasonable is not correct.
  • I am still in possession of the defective strip, which is clear proof of abnormality and unfitness for consumption. 
I remain open to a fair and amicable resolution. However, if Pharmeasy continues to disclaim liability, I will be compelled to pursue remedies before the Consumer Forum, FDA authorities, and CDSCO, seeking damages from both Alembic and Pharmeasy.
Please reconsider your position and come forward with a constructive settlement proposal within 3 days of this email.
Sincerely,
Namrata

a) evidence that no credible investigation was carried out; or
b) deliberate withholding of material information regarding a public-safety defect.
Either conclusion will lead me to file complaints for: deficiency in service, unfair trade practice, negligent handling of drug safety complaints, and pursue remedies before the Consumer Forum and regulatory authorities (FDA/CDSCO). I will also seek disclosure orders for the withheld documents in court.
This is my final communication prior to legal escalation. I expect a full and substantiated reply within 5 working days.
Regards,
Namrata

Hi Team,

Regards,
Axelia Legal Team

---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: namrata adeshra <namrata_adeshra@yahoo.com>
Date: Tue, Sep 2, 2025 at 11:43 PM
Subject: Response to Your Legal Reply – Defective Medicine Complaint
To: PharmEasy <care@pharmeasy.in>, dhaval@pharmeasy.in <dhaval@pharmeasy.in>, legal@axelia.in <legal@axelia.in>


To,
The Legal & Management Team
Pharmeasy
Dear Sir/Madam,
I acknowledge receipt of your legal response regarding my complaint about the defective strip of Richar CR 100 mg tablets purchased through your platform. After reviewing your reply, I must place the following points on record:
1. Your Role as Seller/Distributor
Pharmeasy acted as the point of sale. You collected payment, facilitated delivery, and positioned yourself as the consumer-facing entity. Under the Consumer Protection Act, 2019, and the Drugs & Cosmetics Act, 1940, you are part of the supply chain and cannot disclaim liability entirely by stating you are “just a third-party platform.” Consumer rights are statutory and cannot be waived by contract.
2. Refund ≠ Resolution
When I first raised the issue in November 2023, Pharmeasy collected the defective strip and issued a refund. This action itself amounts to an acknowledgment that the product was defective and unfit for consumption. However, issuing a refund is not a substitute for investigating the root cause, especially in pharmaceuticals where public health is at stake.
3. Failure to Escalate
Despite evidence of a visibly unsafe drug, Pharmeasy did not escalate the matter to Alembic (the manufacturer) or the FDA authorities. As a licensed distributor, this was your duty. Your inaction meant the potential risk to thousands of patients consuming the same batch was ignored.
3A. Failure to Inspect and Report
By collecting the returned medicine, Pharmeasy assumed custody of defective stock. You had a clear responsibility to inspect it and report the defect to the manufacturer and regulatory authorities. Instead, you treated the issue as a simple financial dispute and closed it with a refund, ignoring your statutory duty of care under the Drugs & Cosmetics Act, 1940.
4. Medicines Are Not Ordinary Goods
Pharmaceuticals are life-critical products. A refund cannot be considered the end of the matter when a product that is supposed to save lives is visibly defective, with a black substance oozing out. Such a defect makes the medicine unfit for human consumption regardless of alleged storage conditions.
5. Recurrence Confirms Negligence
The fact that I experienced the same issue again — and still retain the second defective strip — shows this is not an isolated case. Had Pharmeasy acted responsibly during the first incident, conducted proper inspection, and escalated to Alembic or FDA, this recurrence may have been prevented.
6. Pattern of Denial
Your legal reply attempts to disclaim liability entirely. However, both manufacturer and seller are jointly and severally liable under the Consumer Protection Act, 2019. By refusing to accept any accountability, Pharmeasy creates a dangerous gap in the supply chain where no one takes responsibility for defective medicines.

Final Position

  • Pharmeasy’s handling of this matter reflects negligence and a failure in basic consumer protection obligations.
  • I was accommodating enough to return the first strip in good faith. However, when the issue recurred, my concerns escalated. Calling my stance unreasonable is not correct.
  • I am still in possession of the defective strip, which is clear proof of abnormality and unfitness for consumption. 
I remain open to a fair and amicable resolution. However, if Pharmeasy continues to disclaim liability, I will be compelled to pursue remedies before the Consumer Forum, FDA authorities, and CDSCO, seeking damages from both Alembic and Pharmeasy.
Please reconsider your position and come forward with a constructive settlement proposal within 3 days of this email.
Sincerely,
Namrata

replied
an hour ago (Wed, 3 Dec 2025 at 4:26 PM)
 
To:"Legal Axelia" <legal@axelia.in>
Cc:care@pharmeasy.in
Dear Team,
This email is my final request for clarity and documentary proof regarding the defective Richar CR 100 mg strip supplied via your platform. I set out my demands below — please respond fully within 5 working days. If you do not, I will proceed to file complaints in the Consumer Court and with regulatory authorities.
1. Re-send the promised mail and report
Your agent told me on our call that he would forward the November 1, 2023 email and the investigation summary again. I have not received it. Please forward that exact email and any attachments (or provide server logs/screenshots proving it was sent) immediately.
2. Produce documentary proof of escalation and reply from Alembic
You have repeatedly asserted that you escalated the complaint to Alembic and received their investigation findings. Alembic, however, contends they did not receive such escalation. Provide the following without delay:
  • Copy of the email/request sent by your client to Alembic (with timestamps).
  • Copy of the response/reply from Alembic (with timestamps).
  • Any internal notes, ticket IDs, or attachments exchanged regarding the investigation.
3. Explain who is legally/operationally at fault
If Alembic’s report clears the manufacturer, who is at fault then? As a consumer I require clarity:
  • If the manufacturer is not at fault, has your client identified the retailer/seller from whom the product was procured?
  • Has any action been taken against that retailer (suspension/termination/investigation)?
  • Was any complaint or show-cause initiated against that retailer? Please provide proof.
4. Manufacturing timeline, storage & safety concern
The product was manufactured only 2–3 months prior to the defect becoming visible. If a medicine degrades or shows contamination within such a short period (given the declared shelf life exceeds two years), this is a serious safety concern. Your communications do not address:
  • How a properly manufactured drug could degrade so rapidly;
  • Whether retailers/distributors in the supply chain were audited for storage conditions; and
  • Whether other units from the same batch were identified and quarantined or recalled.
    Provide details and documentary proof.
5. Confidentiality is not a shield in matters of public safety
You continue to refuse to share the manufacturer’s report citing confidentiality. Explain the legal basis for withholding information from the affected consumer: cite the exact statute, rule, or clause that permits you to withhold drug quality investigation summaries from a complainant. If no lawful basis exists, you must disclose the summary of findings to me immediately. Withholding such material in the name of confidentiality, where public safety is implicated, is unacceptable.
6. Retailer/seller accountability & corrective steps
If your client’s investigation finds the manufacturer is not responsible, you must confirm:
  • the identity of the retailer/seller from whom the product was sourced;
  • whether that retailer has been suspended/blocked pending inquiry; and
  • what corrective actions (if any) have been taken to prevent distribution of other affected units. Provide documentary proof.
7. Failure to respond is actionable
If you cannot produce the requested documents or lawful justification for withholding them within 5 working days, I will interpret your silence or non-compliance as:
a) evidence that no credible investigation was carried out; or
b) deliberate withholding of material information regarding a public-safety defect.
Either conclusion will lead me to file complaints for: deficiency in service, unfair trade practice, negligent handling of drug safety complaints, and pursue remedies before the Consumer Forum and regulatory authorities (FDA/CDSCO). I will also seek disclosure orders for the withheld documents in court.
This is my final communication prior to legal escalation. I expect a full and substantiated reply within 5 working days.
Regards,
Namrata

like to reassure you that your complaint has been treated with utmost
seriousness from the very beginning, and all necessary steps were promptly

To:"Legal Axelia" <legal@axelia.in>
Cc:care@pharmeasy.in
Dear Team,
This email is my final request for clarity and documentary proof regarding the defective Richar CR 100 mg strip supplied via your platform. I set out my demands below — please respond fully within 5 working days. If you do not, I will proceed to file complaints in the Consumer Court and with regulatory authorities.
1. Re-send the promised mail and report
Your agent told me on our call that he would forward the November 1, 2023 email and the investigation summary again. I have not received it. Please forward that exact email and any attachments (or provide server logs/screenshots proving it was sent) immediately.
2. Produce documentary proof of escalation and reply from Alembic
You have repeatedly asserted that you escalated the complaint to Alembic and received their investigation findings. Alembic, however, contends they did not receive such escalation. Provide the following without delay:
  • Copy of the email/request sent by your client to Alembic (with timestamps).
  • Copy of the response/reply from Alembic (with timestamps).
  • Any internal notes, ticket IDs, or attachments exchanged regarding the investigation.
3. Explain who is legally/operationally at fault
If Alembic’s report clears the manufacturer, who is at fault then? As a consumer I require clarity:
  • If the manufacturer is not at fault, has your client identified the retailer/seller from whom the product was procured?
  • Has any action been taken against that retailer (suspension/termination/investigation)?
  • Was any complaint or show-cause initiated against that retailer? Please provide proof.
4. Manufacturing timeline, storage & safety concern
The product was manufactured only 2–3 months prior to the defect becoming visible. If a medicine degrades or shows contamination within such a short period (given the declared shelf life exceeds two years), this is a serious safety concern. Your communications do not address:
  • How a properly manufactured drug could degrade so rapidly;
  • Whether retailers/distributors in the supply chain were audited for storage conditions; and
  • Whether other units from the same batch were identified and quarantined or recalled.
    Provide details and documentary proof.
5. Confidentiality is not a shield in matters of public safety
You continue to refuse to share the manufacturer’s report citing confidentiality. Explain the legal basis for withholding information from the affected consumer: cite the exact statute, rule, or clause that permits you to withhold drug quality investigation summaries from a complainant. If no lawful basis exists, you must disclose the summary of findings to me immediately. Withholding such material in the name of confidentiality, where public safety is implicated, is unacceptable.
6. Retailer/seller accountability & corrective steps
If your client’s investigation finds the manufacturer is not responsible, you must confirm:
  • the identity of the retailer/seller from whom the product was sourced;
  • whether that retailer has been suspended/blocked pending inquiry; and
  • what corrective actions (if any) have been taken to prevent distribution of other affected units. Provide documentary proof.
7. Failure to respond is actionable
If you cannot produce the requested documents or lawful justification for withholding them within 5 working days, I will interpret your silence or non-compliance as:
a) evidence that no credible investigation was carried out; or
b) deliberate withholding of material information regarding a public-safety defect.
Either conclusion will lead me to file complaints for: deficiency in service, unfair trade practice, negligent handling of drug safety complaints, and pursue remedies before the Consumer Forum and regulatory authorities (FDA/CDSCO). I will also seek disclosure orders for the withheld documents in court.
This is my final communication prior to legal escalation. I expect a full and substantiated reply within 5 working days.
Regards,
Namrata

---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: namrata adeshra <namrata_adeshra@yahoo.com>
Date: Tue, Sep 2, 2025 at 11:43 PM
Subject: Response to Your Legal Reply – Defective Medicine Complaint
To: PharmEasy <care@pharmeasy.in>, dhaval@pharmeasy.in <dhaval@pharmeasy.in>, legal@axelia.in <legal@axelia.in>


To,
The Legal & Management Team
Pharmeasy
Dear Sir/Madam,
I acknowledge receipt of your legal response regarding my complaint about the defective strip of Richar CR 100 mg tablets purchased through your platform. After reviewing your reply, I must place the following points on record:
1. Your Role as Seller/Distributor
Pharmeasy acted as the point of sale. You collected payment, facilitated delivery, and positioned yourself as the consumer-facing entity. Under the Consumer Protection Act, 2019, and the Drugs & Cosmetics Act, 1940, you are part of the supply chain and cannot disclaim liability entirely by stating you are “just a third-party platform.” Consumer rights are statutory and cannot be waived by contract.
2. Refund ≠ Resolution
When I first raised the issue in November 2023, Pharmeasy collected the defective strip and issued a refund. This action itself amounts to an acknowledgment that the product was defective and unfit for consumption. However, issuing a refund is not a substitute for investigating the root cause, especially in pharmaceuticals where public health is at stake.
3. Failure to Escalate
Despite evidence of a visibly unsafe drug, Pharmeasy did not escalate the matter to Alembic (the manufacturer) or the FDA authorities. As a licensed distributor, this was your duty. Your inaction meant the potential risk to thousands of patients consuming the same batch was ignored.
3A. Failure to Inspect and Report
By collecting the returned medicine, Pharmeasy assumed custody of defective stock. You had a clear responsibility to inspect it and report the defect to the manufacturer and regulatory authorities. Instead, you treated the issue as a simple financial dispute and closed it with a refund, ignoring your statutory duty of care under the Drugs & Cosmetics Act, 1940.
4. Medicines Are Not Ordinary Goods
Pharmaceuticals are life-critical products. A refund cannot be considered the end of the matter when a product that is supposed to save lives is visibly defective, with a black substance oozing out. Such a defect makes the medicine unfit for human consumption regardless of alleged storage conditions.
5. Recurrence Confirms Negligence
The fact that I experienced the same issue again — and still retain the second defective strip — shows this is not an isolated case. Had Pharmeasy acted responsibly during the first incident, conducted proper inspection, and escalated to Alembic or FDA, this recurrence may have been prevented.
6. Pattern of Denial
Your legal reply attempts to disclaim liability entirely. However, both manufacturer and seller are jointly and severally liable under the Consumer Protection Act, 2019. By refusing to accept any accountability, Pharmeasy creates a dangerous gap in the supply chain where no one takes responsibility for defective medicines.

Final Position

  • Pharmeasy’s handling of this matter reflects negligence and a failure in basic consumer protection obligations.
  • I was accommodating enough to return the first strip in good faith. However, when the issue recurred, my concerns escalated. Calling my stance unreasonable is not correct.
  • I am still in possession of the defective strip, which is clear proof of abnormality and unfitness for consumption. 
I remain open to a fair and amicable resolution. However, if Pharmeasy continues to disclaim liability, I will be compelled to pursue remedies before the Consumer Forum, FDA authorities, and CDSCO, seeking damages from both Alembic and Pharmeasy.
Please reconsider your position and come forward with a constructive settlement proposal within 3 days of this email.
Sincerely,
Namrata

I will also seek disclosure orders for the withheld documents in court.
This is my final communication prior to legal escalation. I expect a full and substantiated reply within 5 working days.
Regards,
Namrata

On Fri, Sep 5, 2025 at 12:11 PM Legal Axelia <legal@axelia.in> wrote:
Hi Team,

Kindly refer to the email below and confirm whether we have responded to the customer or had any communication with the customer.

Regards,
Axelia Legal Team

---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: namrata adeshra <namrata_adeshra@yahoo.com>
Date: Tue, Sep 2, 2025 at 11:43 PM
Subject: Response to Your Legal Reply – Defective Medicine Complaint
To: PharmEasy <care@pharmeasy.in>, dhaval@pharmeasy.in <dhaval@pharmeasy.in>, legal@axelia.in <legal@axelia.in>


To,
The Legal & Management Team
Pharmeasy
Dear Sir/Madam,
I acknowledge receipt of your legal response regarding my complaint about the defective strip of Richar CR 100 mg tablets purchased through your platform. After reviewing your reply, I must place the following points on record:
1. Your Role as Seller/Distributor
Pharmeasy acted as the point of sale. You collected payment, facilitated delivery, and positioned yourself as the consumer-facing entity. Under the Consumer Protection Act, 2019, and the Drugs & Cosmetics Act, 1940, you are part of the supply chain and cannot disclaim liability entirely by stating you are “just a third-party platform.” Consumer rights are statutory and cannot be waived by contract.
2. Refund ≠ Resolution
When I first raised the issue in November 2023, Pharmeasy collected the defective strip and issued a refund. This action itself amounts to an acknowledgment that the product was defective and unfit for consumption. However, issuing a refund is not a substitute for investigating the root cause, especially in pharmaceuticals where public health is at stake.
3. Failure to Escalate
Despite evidence of a visibly unsafe drug, Pharmeasy did not escalate the matter to Alembic (the manufacturer) or the FDA authorities. As a licensed distributor, this was your duty. Your inaction meant the potential risk to thousands of patients consuming the same batch was ignored.
3A. Failure to Inspect and Report
By collecting the returned medicine, Pharmeasy assumed custody of defective stock. You had a clear responsibility to inspect it and report the defect to the manufacturer and regulatory authorities. Instead, you treated the issue as a simple financial dispute and closed it with a refund, ignoring your statutory duty of care under the Drugs & Cosmetics Act, 1940.
4. Medicines Are Not Ordinary Goods
Pharmaceuticals are life-critical products. A refund cannot be considered the end of the matter when a product that is supposed to save lives is visibly defective, with a black substance oozing out. Such a defect makes the medicine unfit for human consumption regardless of alleged storage conditions.
5. Recurrence Confirms Negligence
The fact that I experienced the same issue again — and still retain the second defective strip — shows this is not an isolated case. Had Pharmeasy acted responsibly during the first incident, conducted proper inspection, and escalated to Alembic or FDA, this recurrence may have been prevented.
6. Pattern of Denial
Your legal reply attempts to disclaim liability entirely. However, both manufacturer and seller are jointly and severally liable under the Consumer Protection Act, 2019. By refusing to accept any accountability, Pharmeasy creates a dangerous gap in the supply chain where no one takes responsibility for defective medicines.

Final Position

  • Pharmeasy’s handling of this matter reflects negligence and a failure in basic consumer protection obligations.
  • I was accommodating enough to return the first strip in good faith. However, when the issue recurred, my concerns escalated. Calling my stance unreasonable is not correct.
  • I am still in possession of the defective strip, which is clear proof of abnormality and unfitness for consumption. 
I remain open to a fair and amicable resolution. However, if Pharmeasy continues to disclaim liability, I will be compelled to pursue remedies before the Consumer Forum, FDA authorities, and CDSCO, seeking damages from both Alembic and Pharmeasy.
Please reconsider your position and come forward with a constructive settlement proposal within 3 days of this email.
Sincerely,
Namrata

notes.body: Hello,     Greetings from PharmEasy!    With regards to your order #654418129377542144-88342, I can see your order has been dispatched, and it is being delivered by a courier partner. The estimated delivery date is 5th December 2025.  Please note that the estimated date of delivery for courier orders will vary based on the delivery location. Your order will be delivered within the estimated delivery date committed at the time of order placement. Your patience and understanding are highly appreciated in the meantime.  You can also track your order on the link below with the help of the AWB number.  Link: https://www.shiprocket.in/shipment-tracking/ AWB: 9148881031892.     I am sorry to inform you that we are unable to share the delivery boy's number, as this is a third-party courier order.     For any further assistance, please reach out to us through our support channels in the App or website listed in the 'Need Help' section.  Thank you for choosing PharmEasy. Stay Healthy.       Regards,  Devdas.
notes.body_html:
Hello,

Greetings from PharmEasy!

With regards to your order #654418129377542144-88342, I can see your order has been dispatched, and it is being delivered by a courier partner. The estimated delivery date is 5th December 2025.

Please note that the estimated date of delivery for courier orders will vary based on the delivery location. Your order will be delivered within the estimated delivery date committed at the time of order placement. Your patience and understanding are highly appreciated in the meantime.

You can also track your order on the link below with the help of the AWB number. 
Link: https://www.shiprocket.in/shipment-tracking/
AWB: 9148881031892.

I am sorry to inform you that we are unable to share the delivery boy's number, as this is a third-party courier order.

For any further assistance, please reach out to us through our support channels in the App or website listed in the 'Need Help' section.

Thank you for choosing PharmEasy. Stay Healthy.

Regards,
Devdas.

notes.body:
Hello ,

I am writing to clarify my issue regarding the ₹198 refund.

I checked my SBI bank statement, and it shows a refund entry of ₹198, but
the amount has NOT been added to my actual account balance. I also shared
the screenshot from my SBI WhatsApp banking which confirms this.

This means:

The refund has only generated a temporary or shadow entry,

But the money has not been settled/credited to my account.


I request you to please check and confirm:

1. Whether the refund is fully settled from your payment gateway side.


2. Provide the complete refund details (gateway name, transaction
date/time, settlement ID, etc.) so that SBI can trace why the credit has
not been processed.



Please look into this urgently as the refund has still not reached my
usable balance.

Thank you,
Sona
notes.body_html:
Hello ,

I am writing to clarify my issue regarding the ₹198 refund.

I checked my SBI bank statement, and it shows a refund entry of ₹198, but the amount has NOT been added to my actual account balance. I also shared the screenshot from my SBI WhatsApp banking which confirms this.

This means:

The refund has only generated a temporary or shadow entry,

But the money has not been settled/credited to my account.


I request you to please check and confirm:

1. Whether the refund is fully settled from your payment gateway side.


2. Provide the complete refund details (gateway name, transaction date/time, settlement ID, etc.) so that SBI can trace why the credit has not been processed.



Please look into this urgently as the refund has still not reached my usable balance.

Thank you,
Sona

Hello Prashanth,

Greetings from PharmEasy!

With regards to your order #654503045406638080-89591, as checked due to some unforeseen circumstances, the order was not delivered to you by the expected date of delivery. Please accept my apologies for the same.

As per the records, your order is delivered to you on 04th December 2025. We have jotted down the details of your experience and PharmEasy will ensure all appropriate actions are taken to prevent similar situations from happening in the future.

We look forward to having an opportunity to serve you in the future.

We are marking the ticket as resolved. If you have any queries, please feel free to get back to us.

For any further assistance, please reopen this ticket or reach out to us through our support channels, in the App or website, listed in the 'Need Help' section. 

Thank you for choosing PharmEasy. Have a great day ahead!

Regards,
PharmEasy
